Article.Abstract: We have focused on conserved regions of the hepatitis C Virus (HCV) genome to identify viral peptides that contain HLA class I binding motifs and bind with high affinity to the corresponding purified HLA molecules. Accordingly, we have identified 31 candidate epitopes in the HCV that have the potential to be recognized by either HLA-A1, A2.1-, A3, A11- or A24-restricted cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTL). Twelve conserved peptides that bind HLA-A2.1 with high or intermediate affinity were tested for immunogenicity in vitro in human primary CTL cultures and in vivo by direct immunization of HLA-A2.1/Kb transgenic mice. Six HLA-A2.1-restricted CTL epitopes were immunogenic in both systems. At least three of these peptide epitopes were endogenously processed and presented for CTL recognition. Overall, these data illustrate the value of this approach for the development of virus-specific, peptide-based vaccines.
Article.ArticleTitle: Identification of A2-restricted hepatitis C virus-specific cytotoxic T lymphocyte epitopes from conserved regions of the viral genome.
Article.Affiliations: Cytel Corporation, San Diego, CA 92121, USA.
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Amino Acid Sequence; Animals; Conserved Sequence(immunology); Epitopes(immunology); HLA-A2 Antigen(genetics; immunology); Hepacivirus(classification; immunology); Humans; Mice; Mice, Transgenic; T-Lymphocytes, Cytotoxic(immunology); Transfection(immunology)

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: CD8+ T cells, depleted of CD4+ T cells, were immunized in vitro with activated, epitope-loaded and irradiated PBMC in the presence of IL-7 and IL-2 for 12 days. On day 12, the cultures were restimulated with epitope-pulsed adherent PBMC and IL-2 and assayed 7 days later.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: In vitro immunization with the epitope did not induce epitope-specific primary CTL from PBMC of 4 donors.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: CD8+ T cells, depleted of CD4+ T cells, were immunized in vitro with activated, epitope-loaded and irradiated PBMC in the presence of IL-7 and IL-2 for 12 days. On day 12, the cultures were restimulated with epitope-pulsed adherent PBMC and IL-2 and assayed 7 days later.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: In vitro immunization with the epitope induced epitope-specific primary CTL that lysed epitope-loaded JY or 221. A2.1(HLA-A*0201) cells. This epitope elicited a response in 77% of donors (10 of 13) tested.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Mice were injected with 50 µg of epitope and 140 µg of the helper epitope HBV core 128-140 in IFA.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Splenocytes were harvested 11 days after immunization and incubated with epitope-coated, syngeneic LPS blasts and assayed 6 days later.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The epitope induced a CTL response in HLA-A*0201/K<sup>b</sup> transgenic mice. MHC restriction of the response is demonstrated because HLA-A*0201/K<sup>b</sup> is the only class I molecule shared by the transgenic mouse CTL and the HLA-A*0201/K<sup>b</sup>-transfected human Jurkat cell targets.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: CD8+ T cells, depleted of CD4+ T cells, were immunized in vitro with activated, epitope-loaded and irradiated PBMC in the presence of IL-7 and IL-2 for 12 days. On day 12, the cultures were restimulated with epitope-pulsed adherent PBMC and IL-2 and assayed 7 days later.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Primary CTL induced by in vitro immunization of human PBMC with epitope lysed HCV core-transfected 221. A2.1 cells. This shows that the epitope was endogenously processed and presented for CTL recognition.
